newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai central bank defends baht fixing policy.
newsitem.headline: Thai central bank defends baht fixing policy.

text.p: A Thai central bank official on Tuesday defended the policy by which the baht is fixed daily against a basket of currencies, heavily weighted in the U.S. dollar.

"We stick by the integrity of the basket of currencies against which the baht is fixed. We will do whatever is neessary to defend the role of this system," an official in the Bank of Thailand's banking department told Reuters.

He made the comments when asked about reports by forex dealers of a speculative attack on the Thai currency by offshore investors early on Tuesday and that the central bank had spent up to $500 million to defend the currency.
"I cannot comment about interventions," the official said when asked about the reported central bank defence of the baht in the Singapore market.
The baht fell sharply earlier in the day after the offshore speculative attack which came on the back of year-end demand for rising dollars by companies preparing to close their books, dealers said.
Statements by the Finance Minister Amnuay Viravan that the baht was undervalued, contrary to some views that it was overvalued, also helped shore up the currency.
At 0839 GMT, the baht stabilised at 25.595-25.600 to the dollar, after sliding to a day's low of 25.612.
Amnuay said any change in policy to make the system of baht-fixing more flexible or to change it would be considered later, only when it was necessary.
